title: Preferential Behavior in Online Groups
segmentation: Hi, I'm Jasmine Novak from Yahoo Research and I'm going to talk about preferential behavior on an.
Groups, so do you all know the type of person who's super involved in a group?
They keep constant tabs on it.
They check in like every day, many times a day they're part of every conversation going on.
They make sure all the questions are answered.
They make sure that threads are on topic and they're really a leader of the group.
Seems like just about every on line group has at least one or more of these people, and in fact some people believe that a group becomes a community only when such a person is involved.
Do you magine that these folks join a group just like anybody else that they slowly grow an interest and influence until eventually their senior members respected by everybody?
Or do you think that they are treated specially right from the get go?
And have an immediate affinity with the group and the group with them.
While we were wondering this, so we performed some experiments to find out and we found out that.
These folks are treated totally different from the minute they joined the group.
We found three main ways in which these power users are treated differently.
First members who will become heavily engaged power users are 20 times more likely to receive a response when they first join a group.
And later on once they've become heavily engaged, they're still almost twice as likely to receive a response to their messages.
And the early responses to these heavily engage users are nine times more likely to come from a user who will also go on to be a heavily engaged user.
So here's an outline when all about what I'll be talking about.
First, I'll talk a little bit about on line groups.
Then I'll explain what we focused our study on and how we set up our experiments.
We'll look at a few statistics on group cores and heavily engaged users will look at this preferential treatment that are given to these engaged users.
And finally, I'll present a model for predicting which of these users become heavily engaged.
So first I'll talk about.
Oops, I'm sure some of you.
I'm sure all of you are familiar with some kind of online group.
There's a large variety of types.
Some examples are the Ithaca Rotary Club mailing list or the Palo Alto Parenting Group or the Aerosmith Fan Club on Myspace.
Bing.
Mostly from Yahoo.
We decided to focus our study on Yahoo groups, which is one of the largest online collections of groups.
We use data from one year ending in May 2006.
Yahoo groups at the time of our study had roughly 1,000,000 users and six million groups.

I mean 100 million users and six million groups at any user can create a group and that user becomes the moderate are of the group and can control things like the moderate, the memberships in the privacy status.
Users can choose to read and post on line to the boards or send and receive messages by email, and there are about 6 billion mess.
Is.
And some of our studies we break out the groups into categories based on size or on privacy status.
So we define the three levels of size.
I'm small, fewer than 20 unique posters medium which is 20 to 99 posters or large more than 100.
We also define three privacy status categories, public, semi, public and private.
And these are based on the options available to a moderate are when they first create a group.
Things like if a group is listed in the Directory and shows up in search results.
Or whether a non member can post to the.

Some get somewhat involved in the conversations, and others are.

These heavily engaged power users who are really central to the group, and these are the users that we really wanted to focus our study on in order to study these users, we need to focus on groups with some enough signal, some minimum level of activity maintained over a significant period of time.
So we define a notion of.
Thriving groups So what is a thriving group?
Well, it needs three things to be considered thriving at least 10 distinct users must post during the year, and this is the year ending in May 2006.
It must have at least two messages in every 30 day window during the year, and it must have a dense.
In which there are 10 posts in every seven day interval.
There were 44 thousand such groups consisting of 1,000,000 users.
In order to get our hands on this set of engaged users, we developed a notion of K course.
So a user is in the cake or of a group at time T if during a two week interval surrounding T the user was replied to and replied to at least K distinct users.
So in this example.
This user has replied to three users and been replied to by three years or so she would be in the three core.
So before we look at these engaged users, it's interesting to look at this core definition of groups.
This is the cumulative distribution of cake or sizes 1, two, and three.
It's computed for every group for every day of the year.
The X axis is the number of people in the core and the Y axis is the number of group time pairs with at least that many people in the core.
So this shows that very few group Group time pairs have more than 20 users in the two or three core.
Also, the core typically ranges from zero to 10, with about 10% of groups having 10 to 20 users in the core.
One thing to note that is, although in our thriving groups definition we only used activity levels, there is a nontrivial core of engaged users posting and responding.
For example, 48% of group time pairs have at least six people.
And there are two core, so this implies a real response structure and that the engaged users that we're studying are really participating in a community environment.
We can look at the fraction of users of a group that are in the core.
Here we look at our nine categories again.
Size cross privacy status, semi public and private groups behave similarly, but public groups, which is the dark green bar tend to have a lower fraction of their members in the core.
Also, the smaller the group, the larger the fraction of members in the core.
We can also look at the time users tend to spend within the core.
This is the cumulative distribution of the number of days it's getting cut off a little bit, but number of days a user remains in the core, broken out into our nine categories.
The X axis here is the number of days a user spends in the core and the Y axis is the proportion of users who spend that many, many days in the core.
Or less that many days are less in the court.
The small groups show a very different behavior, with users staying in the core for much longer than larger groups.
Also, people in private groups tend to belong to the core for longer than those in public groups.
So if we look at the bottom yellow line that is private small groups only 20% of the users in this category spend less than two weeks in the core and 48% are in the core for over 200 days.

In contrast, the very top line, the green line, is large public groups and 94% of the users in this category are in the core for less than two weeks, so there's a big difference in behavior between these different categories.
Here we look at the churn in the core.
So are these cores the same people all the time?
Are they tend to change here?

The X axis is how long it takes on average for the membership of the core to disappear and the Y axis over half the membership of the core to disappear and the Y axis is the number of groups with that half half life.
So this shows that within about 50 days a lot of the groups have changed substantially.
So there's a significant amount of amount of churn within these cores.
Based on our results, an in some of the charts have shown and others that are in the paper.
We selected 50 days as 50 days in the core as a cutoff point to define these engaged users.
So we use this this to break the members of a group into three categories.
The light users who never joined the core.
The short core members who are in the core but for fewer than 50 days and the long core members are in the core for 50 days or more and these long quorum members.
These are are heavily engaged power users that were really wanting to study.
So most users are light.
If we look at the distribution, but there's a significant fraction of users overall that are in these long and short cores.

For such individuals the proportion of groups that they are long core and the curve decreases almost monotonically from one group to around 20 groups, showing that users are much more likely to belong core users if they belong to a fewer number of groups.

Users in fewer groups are able to focus their attention on these groups at the level necessary to become a heavily engaged user.
So now we'll finally look back again at this preferential treatment of these heavily engaged users.
So we asked this question are engaged or longcore users treated differently within a group?
And yes, we detailed three key forms of preferential treatment given to highly engaged users, and these are the points that I mentioned at the beginning of the slides.
First we looked at the probability a user gets a response right when they first join a group.

So we looked at the 1st 20 messages a user post to a group and calculated the probability that these messages receive a response, broken out again into these nine categories size cross privacy status.
Members will become heavily engaged users.
This is these long core members on the right are 20 times more likely to receive a response to their messages right after joining then a light user.
So for a light user it's about 2% probability that they'll receive response when they first join, and for a long core user or user that just joined the group will go on to become heavily engaged.
It's about 40% probability that their response will their message will receive a response.
And also along for users are roughly twice as likely to receive a response than the short core members.
The second form of preferential treatment.
We noticed that once a user has joined the core at that time, looked at the probability that they receive a response then, so they've already been in the group, and now they're heavily engaged.

And what's the probability that they receive a response and we found that after becoming heavily engaged, those that will stay engaged long term over 50 days are almost twice as likely to receive response than those who will leave the core before 50 days.
And then the other preferential treatment we noticed was in the response type of Members who are new to a group.

So when a joint, if we look at 2 new members, one who will eventually become a heavily engaged long-term along for users, one will remain a light user of the group if they both receive a response to the message the Longcor user is 9 times more likely to receive a response from a central member of the group.
So in this chart, the dark green bar on the long course side, those are.

Those are messages from other long-term members, and it's like 82% of their messages come from other users who will go on to become long core and for the light users, the light blue bar is other responses from other light users, and that's about 72% of their responses come from other light users, so it's kind of like kindred souls communicating with each other.
Finally, we noted an interesting phenomenon when a heavily engaged user joins a group, the probability of receiving response.
It increases at 1st until they join the core and then it begins to decline.
So this on the left is the probability of receiving response when they join the core and on the right is after they've been in the car for 50 days.

What's the probability they joined the core and it's not a huge drop, but it's definitely significant, and while it's easy to postulate why response rate might go up after you've been in a group for awhile, it's a little harder to explain why that would go down, and we don't really have an explanation for this phenomenon.
So that's just a summary again, of the three forms of preferential treatment we noticed given to these.
Engaged users one hypothesis for this preferential treatment is that long core users might join a group of online friends.
For instance, one might join a group of old high school friends and immediately start interacting in the group as it insider.
So we wanted to test this hypothesis.
We looked at 101st posts of Longcore users and try to determine if this user that was joining the group already knew the other group members.
We found that 6% were already friends.
37% were new and were introducing themselves to the group an.
For the rest there was just nothing in the post to suggest whether they knew the group members or not.

Because over a third of these longcore users are strangers to the group, it suggests that the heavily engaged users receive this special treatment because of their personal characteristics or their fit with the group, or some combination.
So the standard way that you might imagine a new user becoming heavily engaged is that the user joins issues.
A few tentative posts receive some preliminary responses and then slowly grows and reputation to become one of these heavily engaged users.
But this doesn't fit with what we are data and what we discovered.
In fact, one could say that these heavily engaged users are born at the time they join the group, rather than made overtime as one might suspect.

Aged.

First, it may be that a person has some intrinsic quality that causes her to become long core member of a group.
We call that the user factor, or there might be something about the group itself.
It's a particularly interesting or welcoming group that causes a lot of its members to become longcore.
We call that the group factor and of course it may be a combination of both these factors.

Then we evaluate the quality of a set of probabilities by calculating the likelihood of predicting H. We looked at three variants using only the properties of users, in which case we constrain the group probability to be 0.
Using only the properties of groups, in which case we constrain the user probability to be 0 or allowing both probabilities to be arbitrary.
Looking at the results, we see that the user only model does very well about 95% while using the group only model does much worse only 8585.6%.

However, much of this difference is due to the fact that a lot of the users belong to a single group, so these users are modeled perfectly using the user only version and imperfectly using the group only case.

So in conclusion, we perform social analysis on one of the world's largest collections of online communities.
Yahoo groups.

We looked at a few levels of engagement, light, short, korpan, longcore, or heavily engaged an we identified several ways in which these heavily engaged users are given preferential treatment compared to the other members of the group.
And finally we proposed a model to study factors contributing to long-term engagement, and showed that both the user and the group factors both play a role.
